value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">sense of being part of the audience: we <del>cannot for</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">miss a thousand <del>hints that</del> <del>stresses</del> shades</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">that the <del>play</del> dramatist brought out <del>in</del> by</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">inflection, gestures, [placings?] <add place="above">plays</add>. Anybody</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>can test</del> this <add place="above">can be tested</add> by comparing the impressions</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">after seeing 
            <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-wsha" key="Shakespeare, William"><choice>
              <sic>Sh<hi rend="superscript">re</hi></sic>
              <corr>Shakespeare</corr>
            </choice></rs> acted, & after reading the play</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>But,</del> as the modern author inevitably</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">imports much that is foreign to 
            <choice>
              <sic>Sh<hi rend="superscript">re</hi></sic>
              <corr>Shakespeare</corr>
            </choice></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">still <del>as</del> <del>a gap</del> <del>as</del> a dead, <del>no</del> loss: <del>an</del> <add place="above">there is</add> something sunk <add place="inline">beyond recall.</add></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>That</del> The damage inflicted on the early</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">plays by reading them only is very great. The</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">reader instinctively tries, <del>for example,</del> in</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">reading to be <add place="above">there in [person?]</add> at the play. He <del>instinctively</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>imagines</del> the trumpets & the flags: the presence</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">of the citizens & apprentices: He does what he</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">can to supply what is so obviously a part of</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>the</del> <del><rs ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-gamme" type="literary-work" key="Gammer Gurton's Needle">Gammer Gurton Needle,</rs> of <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/lit-woma" key="Woman Killed with Kindness, A">A Woman Killed</rs></del></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">play. At some point in 
            <choice>
              <sic>E<hi rend="superscript">tn</hi></sic>
              <corr>Elizabethan</corr>
            </choice> drama,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">however, the reader is born. There are scenes</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">or speeches that call upon his <del>reader</del> special</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">faculty. <del>It is</del> When the dramatist becomes</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">[curious?] of play as a work of art, when there is</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">a conection <del>between the</del> scenes, <del>when we can</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>still feel the</del> <del>presenting</del> connecting them</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">not because the plot drives him <del>to</del> forward</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">but because he has another unity in mind,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">it is this apprehension <del>that</del> <del>gr</del> <del>transforms</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">brings <del>the reader into</del> it is this apprehension that</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>draws the</del> focuses <del>the</del> [wither?] those faculties</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">which are the readers.</l>

<add xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" place="margin">
            <l>But he is</l>
            <l>perpetually baffled.</l>
            <l>He is apt to</l>
            <l>become <del>not</del> a</l>
            <l>student, not a</l>
            <l>reader: a</l>
            <l>scientist</l>
            <l>collecting the</l>
            <l>bones of the</l>
            <l>extinct</l>
            <l>animal.</l>
          </add>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the <del>reader's faculty</del> To write the life of the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">reader <del>from Elizabeth</del> for the past three hundred years:</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">to discover at what point his ear loses its</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">acuteness: when his eye became dull; when,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">to balance these losses, he became word conscious,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>when time supplied</del> conscious of the suggestions</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">& echoes, &, as time passed, added</l>
